item.title: Trump’s Tariff Chaos Threatens His Push for Rust Belt Revival
item.description: President Donald Trump’s signature trade policy is threatening to backfire by upending other top priorities: the revival of US manufacturing and the American Rust Belt.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette, Miranda Davis, Brooke Sutherland

item.title: Taiwan Exports to US Hit Record as Two Sides Talk Trade
item.description: Taiwan’s exports to the US jumped to a record, surging as companies fired off shipments before any tariffs hit — gains that come as the two sides try to hammer out a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: An image of a semiconductor wafer. Photographer: I-Hwa Cheng/Bloomberg

item.title: Europe Must Defend Rule of Law Standards, ECB’s Elderson Says
item.description: Europe can foster economic well-being and help increase the euro’s global role by adhering to and even strengthening rule of law standards, European Central Bank Executive Board member Frank Elderson said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alessandra Migliaccio

item.title: ECB Nearly or Already at the End of Easing Cycle, Kazimir Says
item.description: The European Central Bank is nearly, if not already, at the end of its cycle of interest-rate cuts, according to Governing Council member Peter Kazimir.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) beyond containers at a freight terminal in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. The European Central Bank is about to lower interest rates for the sixth time since June, though a volatile economic backdrop is sowing divisions over where to take borrowing costs from here.

item.title: China Exports to US Fall Most Since 2020 Despite Trade Truce
item.description: Chinese exports rose less than expected last month as the worst drop in shipments to the US in more than five years counteracted strong demand from other markets.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

item.title: Japan Should Use Asia Trade Bloc in US Talks, Party Chief Says
item.description: Japan should take a bigger role in a regional free trade agreement and use its expansion as a bargaining tool in tariff negotiations with the US, the leader of the country’s largest opposition party said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: S. Korea’s Lee, Japan’s Ishiba Vow to Boost Ties in First Call
item.description: South Korea’s President Lee Jae-myung and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba held their first phone conversation and vowed to seek ways to deepen bilateral ties so both nations can respond together to future challenges.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Sakura Murakami

item.title: China’s Rare Earth Exports Recover Ahead of US Trade Talks
item.description: Chinese exports of rare earths, a group of 17 minerals at the center of a trade dispute with Washington, rose 23% in May from the previous month, according to customs data on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rogers

item.title: BOE Risks Repeat of Brexit Pessimism as Growth Signals Diverge
item.description: Bank of England rate-setters risk underestimating the strength of the UK economy by placing too much faith in downbeat business surveys over official growth data.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: China Consumer Deflation Streak Persists as Price Wars Rage
item.description: China’s consumer deflation extended into a fourth month, as price wars intensified while a spending boost during two national holidays failed to offset the drag from weak domestic demand.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Jing Li

item.title: US, China to Resume Trade Talks With Focus on Rare Earths
item.description: The US and China are set to resume trade negotiations in London on Monday in a bid to further defuse tensions over rare-earth minerals and advanced technology following a phone call between leaders Donald Trump and Xi Jinping last week.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Daniel Flatley

item.title: Japan Confirms GDP Contraction, Backing BOJ’s Cautious Stance
item.description: Japan’s economy contracted in the first quarter, a revised estimate confirmed Monday, weakness that supports the Bank of Japan’s cautious stance and keeps political pressure on Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba ahead of a key election.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Carbon Border Taxes Put South Africa Exports at Risk, Study Says
item.description: South Africa’s key export industries are becoming increasingly vulnerable as climate policies like cross-border carbon taxes take hold, according to a study by Net Zero Tracker.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Vapor rising from the chimneys of the Eskom Holdings SOC Ltd. Kusile coal-fired power plant in Mpumalanga, South Africa, on Friday, Jan. 17, 2025. A rare moment of investor goodwill for South Africa’s most indebted company is being tested by its inability to collect a staggering $5 billion in unpaid bills from cities and towns across the country.

item.title: US Inflation to Tick Higher as Tariffs Reach Consumers
item.description: US consumers probably saw slightly faster inflation in May, notably for merchandise, as companies gradually pass along higher import duties.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

item.title: US Seeks Deal in London on China Rare Earth Flows, Hassett Says
item.description: US negotiators will aim to restore the flow of critical minerals when they meet their Chinese counterparts for a new round of trade negotiations Monday in London, a top economic aide to President Donald Trump said.
item.dc:creator: Vincent Lee

media:content.media:description: Various rare earth minerals on display in a showroom at the Baotou Jiangxin Micro Motor Technology Co., in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China, on Thursday, June 1, 2023. Traditionally a center for coal and steel, the city is marketing itself as the “World’s Green Silicon City,” to lure factories that process the metal needed for semiconductors with low-cost, renewable power.

item.title: Macron Says Subsidy for Energy Efficient Homes Should Go On
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron called on his government to continue a home renovation subsidy program after the finance ministry said it would temporarily halt the grants.
item.dc:creator: Ania Nussbaum

item.title: ECB’s Schnabel Says Now Is Right Time to Boost Role of Euro
item.description: European Central Bank Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel sees a favorable moment now to strengthen the euro’s global role as investors turn to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: US Trade Team Said to Extend India Stay as Talks Gather Momentum
item.description: A US trade team that’s currently in India for negotiations has extended its stay, according to people familiar with the matter, in a sign talks are progressing ahead of a July deadline.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A container ship docked at the Mundra Port of Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc. item.title: ECB Has Maximum Flexibility on Interest Rates, Nagel Tells DLF
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Joachim Nagel said he can’t judge if interest-rate cuts are over for this year and next steps are totally open, according to an interview with Deutschlandfunk.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Verena Sepp

media:content.media:description: Joachim Nagel, president of the Deutsche Bundesbank, during a presentation of the Bundesbank's 2024 Annual Report in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. German parties should quickly form a new government after Sunday’s election, to help prevent the economy failing to expand for a third straight year, according to Nagel.

item.title: ECB’s Central Rate Scenario May Need Fine-Tuning, Escriva Says
item.description: The assumptions currently guiding European Central Bank monetary policy may need tweaking, according to Governing Council member Jose Luis Escriva.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: Jose Luis Escriva, governor of Spain's central bank, during a panel session at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday, Jan. 23, 2025. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 20 to 24.

item.title: Labour’s Big Worry Is No One Will Feel Record Spending Surge
item.description: Britain’s Labour government will make an historic investment into the country’s battered public services this week — a £300 billion ($406 billion) uplift for areas such as health care, education and transport, amounting to the largest sustained funding increase since at least 2010.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

item.title: UK Timeline for US Deal Is Too Ambitious, Ex-Trade Adviser Says
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer would need President Donald Trump to be “extraordinarily generous” to meet his ambition of finalizing the UK-US tariff deal in two weeks, according to Britain’s former top trade negotiator.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Jack Ryan

item.title: Reeves to Announce £86 Billion for Science and Technology in Spending Review
item.description: Research into drug treatments and longer-lasting batteries will receive new funding as part of an £86 billion package for science and technology set to be announced in next week's spending review.

item.title: ECB Is in Good Position on Rates, Lagarde Tells Monaco Info
item.description: The latest interest-rate moves primes the European Central Bank to meet its medium-term inflation goal, President Christine Lagarde told television station Monaco Info.

item.title: China Approves Some Exports of Rare Earths Ahead of US Talks
item.description: Beijing says it granted approval to some applications for the export of rare earths, a move that could ease tensions before trade negotiations between the US and China next week.

item.title: BOE’s Greene Sees Disinflation Continuing Despite Near-Term Hump
item.description: Bank of England rate-setter Megan Greene said disinflation in the UK is set to continue despite an acceleration in consumer-price growth in the near term.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Megan Greene, member of the monetary policy committee of the Bank of England, during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Thursday, Nov. 16, 2023. Greene said interest rates will need to remain higher for longer to control inflation and that the structure of the UK economy may have changed since the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Don’t Count on a Sustained Fed-ECB Decoupling, Schnabel Says
item.description: It would be wrong to expect a persistent policy divergence between the US Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, according to Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers
